The light beam is parallel to the central symmetry axis and incident on the outer surface of the hemisphere.
The outer radius of the hemisphere is \( R' = \sqrt{2}R \).
The refractive index of the glass is \( n = \sqrt{2} \).
The light undergoes refraction at the outer surface.
The angle of incidence at the outer surface is 0 degrees because the light is parallel to the axis.
The angle of refraction inside the glass is calculated using Snell's Law: \( n_1 \sin 	heta_1 = n_2 \sin 	heta_2 \).
Since \( n_1 = 1 \) (air) and \( 	heta_1 = 0^\circ \), the angle of refraction \( 	heta_2 = 0^\circ \).
The light travels straight through the glass without bending.
The light reaches the inner surface of the hemisphere.
The inner radius of the hemisphere is \( R \).
To prevent light from exiting the inner surface, the light-blocking plate must cover the entire inner radius.
The radius \( d \) of the light-blocking plate must be equal to the inner radius \( R \).
